notes:
1. The Framework

Hypothesis testing is a statistical method used to make inferences about a population parameter based on sample data. It involves comparing two competing hypotheses.

2. Null and Alternative Hypotheses

  • Null Hypothesis ($H_0$): The assumption of "no effect" or "no difference". It represents the status quo. Examples: $\mu = 10$, $\mu_1 = \mu_2$. It always involves an equality ($=, \le, \ge$).
  • Alternative Hypothesis ($H_a$ or $H_1$): The claim we are testing for; the "new" theory. Examples: $\mu \ne 10$, $\mu_1 < \mu_2$. It never involves an equality ($<, >, \ne$).

3. Test Statistics

To decide between $H_0$ and $H_a$, we calculate a test statistic (like a z-score or t-score) from the sample data. This statistic measures how far our sample estimate deviates from the hypothesized null parameter, in units of standard error.

$$ z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}} \quad \text{or} \quad t = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{s / \sqrt{n}} $$

4. Errors in Decision Making

  • Type I Error ($\alpha$): Rejecting $H_0$ when it is actually true (False Positive).
  • Type II Error ($\beta$): Failing to reject $H_0$ when it is actually false (False Negative).
  • Power ($1-\beta$): The probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis.

solvedExamples.question: Which of the following is a valid statement for a Null Hypothesis ($H_0$)?
solvedExamples.explanation: Hypotheses are always statements about population parameters (like $\mu$), not sample statistics (like $\bar{x}$). Furthermore, the Null Hypothesis must always contain a condition of equality ($=, \le, \ge$). The Alternative Hypothesis contains the inequality.

solvedExamples.question: Failing to reject the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is actually true is known as a:
solvedExamples.explanation: A Type II error (beta) is a 'miss' or a false negative. It occurs when there really is an effect (the null is false), but the test fails to detect it.
